title: Skin care brand Sunday Riley wrote fake Sephora reviews for years, FTC claims
text:
Skincare brand Sunday Riley has been accused of writing fake reviews on Sephora's website for nearly two years to boost sales.

The Texas-based company founded in by CEO Sunday Riley agreed to settle with the Federal Trade Commission Monday over the claims. But while the FTC did not require the company to admit to writing the fake reviews or refund costumers, the company promised not to do so in the future.

The FTC alleges that between November 2015 and August 2017, Sunday Riley employees used fake accounts to post the fake reviews on Sephora's site under the direction of Riley herself.

The investigation found that in July 2016, Riley sent an email to staff instructing them to create three different accounts on Sephora's website, using three different identifies, create fake email accounts, make up names, cities and skin types in order to post positive reviews and boost sales.

The Texas-based company founded by CEO Sunday Riley (pictured) settled with the Federal Trade Commission Monday over the claims

The FTC began its investigation into the company after a former employee posted on Reddit in October 2018, saying Sunday Riley was faking reviews

The FTC concluded: 'On multiple occasions between November 2015 and August 2017, Sunday Riley Skincare managers, including Respondent Sunday Riley, posted reviews of Sunday Riley brand cosmetic products on the Sephora website using fake accounts.

'Numerous reviews of Sunday Riley brand products on the Sephora website did not reflect the independent experiences or opinions of impartial ordinary users of the products because they were written by Sunday Riley and her employees.

'Rather than relying on satisfied customers to generate real buzz about her products, she directed her employees to write glowing reviews and bury negative ones, while offering detailed instructions on how to avoid detection.'

The FTC began its investigation into the company after a former employee posted on Reddit in October 2018, saying Sunday Riley was faking reviews.

At the time, the brand admitted on Instagram that they 'did encourage people to post positive reviews at the launch of this product.'

Skincare brand Sunday Riley is accused of writing fake reviews on Sephora's website for nearly two years

Sunday Riley is a higher-priced brand, with serums ranging from $40 to $105

The FTC claims that Riley told employees to write reviews that were 'very enthusiastic without looking like a plant.'

'It helps to make yourself seem relatable - like you know how hard acne is and you've tried everything, and this one actually works,' the email read.

Riley also allegedly told staffers to 'dislike' negative reviews in order to get them hidden from the Sephora site.

'If you see a negative review - DISLIKE it,' Riley said in one of her emails. 'After enough dislikes, it is removed. This directly translates to sales!!'

The email also provided instructions on how to install a VPN so reviews can't be traced back to the company's IP address.

Sunday Riley is higher-priced brand, with serums ranging from $40 to $105.

FTC commissioners Rohit Chopra and Rebecca Kelly Slaughter said in a letter: 'Fake reviews distort our markets by rewarding bad actors and harming honest companies. The problem is growing, and the Federal Trade Commission should attack it.'
description: The Texas-based company founded by CEO Sunday Riley settled with the Federal Trade Commission Monday over the claims that it wrote fake reviews for two years.
